While we are on the subject, here is one ending later tonight.
Is that thick lacquer covering the surface?
http://cgi.ebay.com/Tsuba-JAPANESE-GENUINE-SWORD-GUARD-Shingen-Tsuba-Rare_W0QQitemZ280168553941QQihZ018QQcategoryZ95132QQssPageNameZWDVWQQrdZ1QQcmdZViewItem

Brian

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Peter A Bleed <pbleed1@...> wrote:
>
>
> Friends,
> While we are on the subject of Shingen tsuba, and since Tom brought them
> up, I have always wondered why both woven wire style and the makade
style
> guards are considered "Shingen." They seem basically different and
> unrelated. It is simply that they both involve use of wire, or is there
> something else going on?
> And, BYT, to follow up Ron's comments, both of those style seem
different
> from those real chunky tsuba you see from time to time in which a
> plane-jane sukashi iron guard has had some wire wrapped on it. These
always
> look to me like recent junk. Am I missing something there, too?
> Peter
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Thank you!
messages.msgSnippet: Because if I didn t collect them, it would be silly to have the nickname the mantis dude .HAHA.  it was actually my first tsuba given to me and it just took.
messages.messageBody:
Because if I didn't collect them, it would be silly to have the nickname "the mantis dude".HAHA. it was actually my first tsuba given to me and it just took. you can read all my symbolizing section on the site , so you can understand why I like it from what it represents. It is just something I found luckily and have only collected it since. It has now been a decade. I have some more pieces that aren't on the site. At some point I will update. I would love pics, but those go into my personal folder. I only post my collection and repros. Still I collect pics that aren't in my collection as reference for myself. I enjoy getting a new piece and having to research the school etc. helps learn a little about a different school. I like how they are available but not so much as dragons, so they are a lot less common than some of the other designs but not so much that I can't find them at all.. Look forward to the pics. Maybe one day I will post
all the photos I have but that is a lot of work. I also don't know how people feel about posting photos from their websites. I didn't keep track of where everywhere I got them from. Anyway, thanks again.
Ken aka "the Mantis Dude"

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] How to call this odd one?
messages.msgSnippet: Friends, While we are on the subject of Shingen tsuba, and since Tom brought them up, I have always wondered why both woven wire style and the makade style
messages.messageBody:
Friends,
While we are on the subject of Shingen tsuba, and since Tom brought them
up, I have always wondered why both woven wire style and the makade style
guards are considered "Shingen." They seem basically different and
unrelated. It is simply that they both involve use of wire, or is there
something else going on?
And, BYT, to follow up Ron's comments, both of those style seem different
from those real chunky tsuba you see from time to time in which a
plane-jane sukashi iron guard has had some wire wrapped on it. These always
look to me like recent junk. Am I missing something there, too?
Peter

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Thank you!
messages.msgSnippet: ... It certainly means someone thought it was, but that doesn t mean much. I have seen known repos go for alot.  Most of us have (most of us have also been the
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "yecheal" <yecheal@...> wrote:
>
> This tsuba was recently sold for JPY 71,000.
> Does this mean it is an original? Is this the avarage value?
>

It certainly means someone thought it was, but that doesn't mean much.
I have seen known repos go for alot. Most of us have (most of us
have also been the one to bid high as well at one point or another) I
don't follow that particular style so pricing isn't something I will
comment on. The one thing I am learning is that there were a lot of
"copies" made in the early 1800's, so they are old in one respect, but
they aren't the real deal. Then there all the copies made in the late
1800's that were more for the international/tourist markets. I don't
have a teacher and have been blowing my opportunities to be with other
collectors. I was so excited joining the NY token kai with access to
many knowledgeable people. But between my health issues and my kids
usually visiting me the weekend the club meets has put a huge damper
on me being able to go. I was picking up things here and there though
and it all goes back to the iron or base metals used. You start to
recognize the metal from the 1800's which is trying to imitate but
usually it is a bit overdone. I wish I could spend more time with
knowledgeable folks. I have to make my way back to the token kai.
Pricing by the way is something that I have struggled with since the
beginning. I think it just takes time to get an idea of where a piece
price range falls into. This is not an exact science by any means.
And unfortunately, the advice I was given on what it's worth hold
true, " it is worth whatever someone else is willing to pay for it".
Not a lot of practical help. So much too learn. Good luck and just
keep plugging at it. As Jim Gilbert says just keep on looking at
them, after feeling and studying over 10,000 you will start to get an
idea. Don't let that number discourage you, just keep at it. Best of
luck and remember the most important thing about collecting sword
fittings, Send all Praying Mantis themed fittings to me. LOL.
Thanks,
Ken aka "the mantis dude"
http://www.freewebs.com/kamakiriken/index.htm

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] How to call this odd one?
messages.msgSnippet: Not sure where I read this, but my understanding is that these tsuba were made from the spoked tsuba that we often see. I guess that could be proven if a
messages.messageBody:
Not sure where I read this, but my understanding is that these tsuba were made from the "spoked" tsuba that we often see. I guess that could be proven if a "mukade" tsuba were unwrapped...but of course, that would be a major sin!

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Tom Helm
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, November 04, 2007 12:41 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] How to call this odd one?


Yecheal -
Not sure how to address you, this is called a Shingen or Mukade
tsuba. Not so odd to those who have been around the study for awhile.
These are so called as it is said, but has not been proven, that
Takeda Shingen's hand-picked personal guard and messenger unit the
Mukade-Tai wore these on their swords. Shingen himself is said to
have awarded these as badges of merit to his troops. For this reason
they are quite popular and there have been many copies of this design.
Your example looks to be all copper given that the surface of the
seppa-dai appears to have been hammered and there are tiny stars
punched into the surface. Originals if such a thing exists are indeed
copper or brass wire woven thru an iron plate. Mukade BTW means
Centipede...
-t

> img600x399-1193623914p1010984.jpg
